> In a class (see below) with two public methods A & B that both call
> pri=
vate
> method C, what's the best approach for unit testing it? Should test
=
> scenarios for A or B cover what may happen in C ? If so, is it just

I su=
spect that the method signatures on A(), B() and C() have been left
out for=
 brevity. I don't know of any good answer to as general a
situation as this=
. Does C() actually take no parameters, and changes
state of the class, or =
does C() get passed in the same kind of
parameters from A() and B()? In the=
 former case, maybe it does need to
be a private method. In the latter, mig=
ht C() be pulled out as a public
method into a helper class?

> If you use =
TDD would you ever end up with private methods, declaring
them
> as protect=
ed instead?

IMHO, it doesn't make sense to make private methods protected =
simply to
test them. "protected" has a specific purpose in the language, an=
d
unless you are expecting people to write subclasses and override those
me=
thods, they probably shouldn't become protected...

Just my 2 cents...

Reg=
ards,
Nilesh
